Med vetskap om vad du vet om ditt partis förmågor (och deras stridsroller, om du så vill) kan skapandet av möten enligt dessa linjer möjliggöra roligt taktiskt tänkande på båda sidor av DM-skärmen.

entries.name: Sample Encounter Compositions
entries: Alla exempel på möten nedan utgår från ett parti med fyra medlemmar och en grundbudget på fyra MP. Använd gärna dessa exempel på möten i ditt eget spel och gör de anpassningar som behövs.

Kom ihåg att du i alla möten, särskilt när de innehåller underhuggare, kan lägga till monster som är mycket svagare än en vanlig underhuggare. Till exempel kan en Fragile Boss-strid för en grupp med karaktärer på 15:e nivån inkludera fyra wights som underhuggare, men du kan också inkludera en hord med tjugo zombies om du känner att wights inte kommer att kunna dra sin egen vikt.

entries.caption: Kill or Capture Squad: Hard Encounter

entries.name: Mid-Combat Encounter Adjustments
entries: Ingen uppsättning regler eller riktlinjer är perfekt. Även om de flesta av dina möten bör fungera smidigt kommer det att finnas tillfällen då du inser att det du skickade till dem antingen är för lätt eller för svårt. Helst kan sådana fall undvikas eller minimeras med tiden. Om du hamnar i en sådan situation kan du prova ett eller flera av följande:

items: Utnyttja det faktum att inte alla fiender kommer att slåss till döden. Om ett monster har låga HP kan det välja att springa iväg istället för att slåss, även om du som DM vet att de potentiellt skulle kunna besegra gruppen.

Förändra ett monsters HP på lämpligt sätt. Genom att sänka HP kan du förhindra att en kamp blir omöjlig eller känns som en slitning, och genom att öka HP kan du förhindra att kampen slutar tidigare än du trodde.

Avstå från att använda en viss förmåga. Till exempel kan en {@creature chain devil}'s förmåga Animate Chains tredubbla sin skadegörelse per runda, men ditt sällskap kanske inte klarar av en sådan ökning. Att inte använda den här förmågan, eller att bara använda den när kedjedjävulen har halva HP eller lägre, kan få mötet att kännas mer rättvist för dina spelare.

entries.name: Encounter Building: By XP
entries: Du kanske har märkt att systemet för att bygga möten ovan täcker ett brett spektrum av utmaningsnivåer med sina nivåer. Detta skapar mer utrymme för att justera dina monsters CRs. Men det döljer också en mycket större brist i systemet, som vi kommer att diskutera och åtgärda nedan.

entries.name: One Versus Many
entries: Som vi tidigare har diskuterat spelar handlingsekonomi en stor roll. Ett solomonster utan legendariska handlingar kommer att bli överväldigad av gruppen, medan en stor svärm av svagare monster kan göra det motsatta. Därför är det nödvändigt att ta hänsyn till det när du balanserar dina möten.

Saken är den att systemet för att bygga upp möten i föregående avsnitt, liksom det som presenteras i {@book Xanathar's Guide to Everything|xge}, inte alls tar hänsyn till detta. I mitt fall väger en mästare lika mycket som två eliter, fyra standards eller sexton hantlangare. Men i ett verkligt möte kan inkluderandet av fyra standardmonster göra kampen mycket svårare för gruppen än vad inkluderandet av två eliter skulle göra. Och även om man tar hänsyn till effektområdesbesvärjelser som {@spell fireball} kan sexton hantlangare utgöra ett stort hot mot gruppen om förutsättningarna är de rätta. Om du inte balanserar handlingsekonomin separat när du gör ett möte, kan det leda till att partiet blir utplånat om du använder något av dessa system planlöst.

entries.name: The Original System
entries: {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|dmg} är ett exakt system för balansering av möten som bygger på XP-värdena för monstren i mötet. För att ta hänsyn till handlingsekonomin lägger de till ett extra steg i processen som heter "Modify Total XP for Multiple Monsters". Under detta sista steg säger DMG att du ska multiplicera monstrens totala XP med en multiplikator som bestäms av antalet monster i mötet.

Konceptet är bra, men multiplikatorerna i sig är meningslösa. De börjar med att ett monster är gånger 1 och ökar när du lägger till fler monster. Men vi vet redan att solomonster i allmänhet tenderar att bli "dogpiled". Borde inte multiplikatorn på 1 gälla när det finns lika många kombattanter på båda sidor? På tal om det, varför tar dessa multiplikatorer inte hänsyn till varierande gruppstorlekar överhuvudtaget? Slutligen, varför presenteras multiplikatorerna för specifika områden av monstergruppernas storlek, vilket leder till att det bildas betydande klyftor mellan dem alla?

entries.name: Tweaking the System
entries: Låt oss ändra steg 4 i DMG:s process för att skapa möten genom att skapa våra egna multiplikatorer och ta hänsyn till de klagomål som presenterats ovan.
Först och främst måste vi ta hänsyn till partiets storlek. De multiplikatorer vi kommer fram till bör delas med antalet partimedlemmar.

Next, let's establish a multiplier of 1 for when the number of monsters equals the number of players. Having less monsters should yield a multiplier of less than 1, and having more should yield a multiplier that is greater than 1.

Finally, let's make this new multiplier formula more precise by not using ranges of monsters, instead creating a continuous function: the function's main input will be the number of monsters, and its output will be the XP multiplier we need.
With all of these facts, we can replace step 4 of the "Creating a Combat Encounter" process in the DMG with the calculation presented below.

entries.name: Revised: Modify Total XP for Multiple Monsters
entries: The more monsters there are in the encounter, the more attack rolls you're making against the characters in a given round, and the more dangerous the encounter becomes. To correctly gauge an encounter's difficulty, multiply the total XP of all the monsters in the encounter by the value given below:

items: If the encounter includes only 1 or 2 monsters, the multiplier is equal to 3 × the number of characters in the party.
If the encounter includes 3 or more monsters, the multiplier is equal to the number of monsters × the number of characters in the party.

entries: When making this calculation, don't count any monsters whose challenge rating is significantly below the average challenge rating of the other monsters in the group unless you think the weak monsters significantly contribute to the difficulty of the encounter.

entries.name: Allied NPCs
entries: Note that if the party has one or more allied NPCs that fight alongside them, they will be able to take on harder encounters. To account for this, you can sum up the XP values for all of those allies, and add them to the encounter's XP budget.

entries.name: Badooga's Encounter Builder
entries: Do you find the very act of building encounters to be tedious? If so, consider making a copy of {@link this|https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1tKf8dBe9TaiT-wxX0Nys47_Z-hDA5Cx8OCLxgPSSXD4/edit?usp=sharing} spreadsheet of mine, which automates both of the Encounter Building methods detailed in this document.

data.name: Running Monsters
entries: So, you know how to create and balance a monster, and you know how to balance an encounter. But how do you actually run the encounter in game?

entries.name: Establishing Motives
entries: While combat is certainly fun as its own pillar of play, it needs to have a reason for occurring within the game world. When building an encounter, you need to establish the goals of all combatants, including the player characters.

entries.name: Party Goals
entries: Monsters generally act as an obstacle that stand in the way of the party's goals. For example, a {@creature displacer beast} might try to interfere with the party's travels, or a band of {@creature kobold|mm|kobolds} might guard the lair of the red dragon the party seeks to slay. To make an encounter interesting, you can try to connect the encounter's circumstances to the party's goals in some way, even if the connection is indirect or incidental.

entries.name: Monster Goals
entries: The players aren't the only creatures with goals in your setting. Even if their goals are simplistic or shallow, a monster will always have some sort of goal in mind when they initiate combat.

Beasts and other animals with similar intellects will generally act on their innate desires to eat and defend themselves. Meanwhile, mindless undead like {@creature zombie|mm|zombies} and {@creature skeleton|mm|skeletons} will seek to kill all living beings unless they are ordered otherwise by their masters.

In contrast, humanoids and other intelligent creatures usually have goals with a level of complexity equal to or greater than those of the party. A gang of {@creature bandit|mm|bandits} might notice the party's valuables and swoop in for a quick score, and an {@creature archdruid} might attempt to defend their sacred grove from the party's meddling. Even the compulsions of a mad {@creature cultist} are often guided by the influences of their dark master.

entries.name: Gathered Information
entries: Even if the different combatants have different goals, the amount of information each of them have can create a huge impact on how these goals are expressed.

For example, the party rogue might seek to avenge their father, but if they don't know the killer is the dashing noble they just passed on the street, initiative won't be rolled at all. Similarly, even the noblest of paladins can be tricked into thinking the party is evil and needs to be slain, despite their fact that they have a flawless track record.

Even if combat has already been initiated, certain information might influence the actions taken by each combatant. The party might be willing to pick a fight with a simple bandit brigade, but that would be different if they knew about the powerful dragon they serve under.
Whatever the case may be, whenever you design an encounter, be sure to account for what the combatants know, which is separate than what the DM knows.

entries.name: Initiating and Ending Combat
entries: It is clear from the last section that when monsters encounter the party, they aren't necessarily out for blood. Monsters have their own goals, which can influence when and how combat is initiated and resolved.

entries.name: Rolling Initiative
entries: Initiative is usually rolled when combat starts, but it can also be rolled just beforehand. If the players encounter one or more monsters that aren't immediately hostile, you can have them roll initative so that you can properly resolve each of their actions sequentially.

Suppose the party and a {@creature displacer beast} come across each other in a forest. Initiative is rolled, but on its turn, the displacer beast doesn't attack. Even though the displacer beast is evil and hunts for sport, it knows that it is outnumbered, and that isn't hidden like it would prefer. Instead of attacking, the beast slowly backs off and retreats into the woods. If the party obliges, the combat then ends... that is, until the displacer beast returns to stealthily hunt the party alongside its pack.

Intelligent creatures in particular are prone to not attacking immediately. Despite its bloodlust, a demon might ignore the party altogether, instead continuing to carry out its masters orders. A passing bandit brigade might allow the party to pass if they aren't in any position to shake them down. Even an insane cultist might yell gibberish at the party in an attempt to get them to leave. That said, some adventuring parties might choose to attack immediately in all three of these scenarios. If that happens, the monsters will be forced to defend themselves and counterattack as appropriate.

entries.name: Resolving Combat
entries: If you got in a brawl, would you fight to the death? For the average D&D monster, the answer is no.

Instead of meeting a bloody end, a {@creature displacer beast} might run away, or a group of {@creature bandit|mm|bandits} might lay down their arms and surrender. Even if they have malicious intentions or want to seek revenge at a later date, they would rather lose a single battle than render their lives forfeit.
On the other hand, mindless constructs, oozes, plants, undead, and other creatures might not have the mental capacity to retreat. Others might possess goals that lead them to fight to the death.

Similarly, if the entire party agrees that they are in over their heads, end the initiative order and allow them to retreat. If the monsters wish to continue fighting, shift to the chase rules detailed in the DMG.

entries.name: Tactics
entries: The behavior of a monster in combat can be determined by a number of factors.

entries.name: The Monsters Know What They're Doing
entries: The dominant factor that influences a monster's behavior in combat is its individual features and abilities. {@link The Monsters Know What They're Doing|https://www.themonstersknow.com/} is a blog that discusses a variety of tactics that can be used by specific types of monsters in combat. I recommend checking that blog out if you want tactical advice for specific monster types.

entries.name: Using Ability Scores
entries: We can use a monster's mental ability scores to build a profile for its behavior in combat. Each section below will discuss the general behavior of a monster based on the numerical range its ability scores fall under.

entries.name: Intelligence
entries: A monster's Wisdom score represents its mental acuity, accuracy of recall, and ability to reason. It also represents the sum of all the knowledge it possesses and and can potentially use to its advantage.

The monster most likely cannot speak or understand any languages, and is incapable of using any proper tactics in combat. It has a poor memory and will act only on instinct (or the commands given to it).

The monster might have a rudimentary understanding of language, but will not have the intellect required to build or create anything more than a simple shelter. If it can be communicated with, it is easily confused by anything more than a superficial overview of basic concepts.

The monster has a general sense of deductive reasoning and can use that reasoning to solve puzzles and to determine what course of action it should take in combat. However, the monster might have trouble thinking ahead or making more than a handful of logical connections at the same time.
The monster can use logic to extrapolate missing information, think ahead and strategize, and can apply knowledge drawn from its previous experiences to the current situation.

The monster has an above average understanding of logic and possesses plenty of knowledge regarding multiple topics. In combat, the monster can overcome the obstacles ahead of it by recalling specific information about its enemies and predicting what actions they will take ahead of time.

The monster is smarter than most humanoid creatures, and may possess an intricate understanding of a wide variety of topics. It can think many steps ahead of most combatants and can plan multiple courses of action to take depending on the behavior of its enemies.
The monster's Intellgence is high enough to rival dragons, planar rulers, and even some deities. In combat, it can apply its vast amount of knowledge to almost any situation it comes across.

entries.name: Wisdom
entries: A monster's Wisdom score represents its intuition and its awareness of the world around it. It also represents how well the monster can apply the information it has to the situation at hand.

The monster is unable to distinguish different creatures from one another without external aid, or it doesn't acknowledge the existence of creatures other than its specific target. Instead of avoiding terrain hazards, the monster might walk straight through them, even if doing so would harm it.

The monster might have a limited understanding of teamwork and cooperation, and can possibly distinguish friend from foe, but it will probably remain oblivious to its surroundings. The creature will also have a semblance of self-preservation and might retreat from battle in certain cases.

The monster will actively avoid any obvious terrain hazards and ensure its own survival as needed. And while it may be able to distinguish certain foes from one another, it might not have a clear understanding of the intentions behind their actions. The monster will also be able to use teamwork as needed.

The monster has a general awareness of the area around it and may take advantage of it when needed. It will be able to read any obvious body language, as well as other signs of the intentions behind another creature's behavior. The monster will also properly recognize its own behavior and how that behavior affects others.

The monster has an above average awareness of the world around it and can keep track of the battle at hand. Its intuition will allow it to understand the bigger picture of the surrounding battle and will know when to retreat or to press onwards.

The monster is wiser than most humanoid creatures, and is capable of outwitting them with ease. Unless a creature is extraordinarily deceptive or intelligent, the monster will be able to read its true intentions with little effort. In battle, it will know the general steps it should take in order to come out on top.
The monster's Wisdom is high enough to rival dragons, planar rulers, and even some deities. In combat, it will be able to use the information it has to achieve the most favorable outcome possible.

entries.name: Morale
entries: In combat, a monster's morale will determine its confidence and whether or not it wants to retreat. You can use or take inspiration from the {@variantrule Morale} optional rule to determine whether or not a creature retreats in a dire situation.

entries.name: Traps, Hazards, and Equipment
entries: Most battles don't take place in empty fields or corridors. They often involve obstacles that grant cover and break line of sight, as well as hazards that the combatants must avoid in order to survive. And on the monsters' home turf, a battle might even include the use of clever traps and siege weapons against unsuspecting adventurers.

entries.name: Traps
entries: Traps are generally made to hinder adventurers and other creatures from traversing through a specific location. However, they can also be used by monsters in the middle of a combat encounter. For example, a deep pit with spikes at the bottom can be cloaked by illusion magic to trick the adventurers into walking into it, but the monsters can also attempt to shove the adventurers into the pit after surprising them in combat.

Whether you are looking for a list of example traps or rules for making custom ones, {@book Dungeon Xanathar's Guide to Everything|xge} includes a comprehensive discussion of traps that I would definitely recommend looking into.
When inserting a trap into an encounter, keeping the following factors in mind:

entries.name: Familiarity
entries: If the monsters made the trap themselves or have had time to experiment with it, they will generally know how to optimize its usage. However, if they aren't too familiar with it, the monsters might use it inefficiently, and even have a chance of harming themselves in the process.

entries.name: Follow-Up
entries: A single trap generally doesn't kill in one hit. It may deal some damage, but it is far more likely that the trap will also impose some sort of condition or other disadvantage that the monsters can capitalize on. For example, if the group of monsters manage to shove the adventurers into the pit of spikes, they can follow up by pouring flaming oil onto these pour souls.

entries.name: Player Usage
entries: The monsters aren't the only ones that can take advantage of a trap. With a keen eye and a sharp wit, it may be possible for the adventurers to turn around and use the trap against the monsters. For example, if the monsters fail to shove the adventurers into the pit of spikes, they in turn might be shoved into it by the adventurers.

entries.name: Hazards
entries: Hazards are similar to traps in function, but are generally not designed or created by any given creature. They also tend to be passive or constantly on, as opposed to the active nature of most traps. With this in mind, you can treat hazards as being similar to traps for the purpose of including them in an encounter.

entries.name: Items and Gear
entries: As discussed in the "Customizing an Existing Monster" section earlier in this document, you can outfit your monsters with mundane or magical items in order to make them more memorable. Remember that the availability and effects of these items will influence the behavior of a monster that wields them. For example, a {@creature goblin} with a {@item potion of healing|dmg} might retreat momentarily in order to drink it, while an {@creature ogre} that consumes a {@item potion of invulnerability} will probably be much more confident and reckless than a regular ogre.

entries.name: Siege Equipment
entries: Even outside of large-scale warfare, you can arm your monsters with powerful {@5etools siege weapons|objects.html} that can give the adventurers a run for their money. Perhaps the outer walls of the {@creature lich}'s castle are guarded by ballistae-wielding {@creature skeleton|mm|skeletons}, or a devious group of {@creature bandit|mm|bandits} have positioned a suspended cauldron of green slime over a bridge to pour on any unsuspecting travelers that try to pass under it.
The sections below expand on the siege equipment entries in the DMG in multiple ways (e.g. adding new projectiles for them to launch).

entries.name: Ballista
entries: {@object ballista|dmg|Ballistae} are similar to crossbows in their design and the projectiles they normally launch. Thus, some ballista variants opt to change the weapon's firing mechanism instead of the projectile itself.
In addition, consider taking inspiration from the alternative cannon projectiles detailed in the next section when designing your own ballista projectiles.

entries.name: Harpoon
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 120/480 ft., one target. {@h} 16 ({@damage 3d10}) piercing damage, and the target is impaled. While impaled, the target can't take any action on its turn other than trying to free itself from the harpoon, which requires a successful DC 15 Strength check. If the check succeeds, the target takes 5 ({@damage 1d10}) piercing damage as the harpoon is pulled free and is no longer impaled. If an action was used to attach the harpoon to the gun by a rope before it was fired, a creature impaled on that harpoon can't move farther away from the gun or increase its altitude until it frees itself. A creature within reach of the gun's winch can use its action to reel in a harpooned creature, pulling it up to 20 feet closer to the gun.

entries.name: Lancer Ballista
entries: These ballista variants are made with advanced engineering that allows them to fire up to three shots at once. It takes one action to load each projectile, one action to aim it, and one action to fire it. When fired, the ballista launches all loaded projectiles at the same target in quick succession.

entries.name: Oversized Javelin of Lightning
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 120/480 ft., one target. {@h} 16 ({@damage 3d10}) piercing damage plus 14 ({@damage 4d6}) lightning damage. As the javelin travels, it transforms into a bolt of lightning, forming a line 5 feet wide that extends out from the ballista to the target. Each creature in the line excluding the ballista and the target must make a DC 14 Dexterity saving throw, taking 14 ({@damage 4d6}) lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Cannon
entries: If gunpowder-based cannons don't make sense in your campaign, you can explain {@object cannon|dmg|cannons} as being powered by magic. To that end, you can use the magical projectiles detailed below instead of a regular cannon ball.

entries.name: Arcane Shot
entries: {@atk rs} {@hit 6} to hit, range 600/2,400 ft., one target. {@h} 44 ({@damage 8d10}) acid, cold, fire, force, lightning, necrotic, or thunder damage (DM's choice).

entries.name: Explosive Shot
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 6} to hit, range 600/2,400 ft., one target. {@h} 44 ({@damage 8d10}) bludgeoning damage, and each creature in a 20-foot-radius sphere centered on the target must make a DC 14 Dexterity saving throw, taking 14 ({@damage 4d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Magic Missile
entries: {@atk rs} automatic hit, range 600 ft., one target. {@h} 21 ({@damage 6d4 + 6}) force damage.

entries.name: Cauldron
entries: Note that a {@object Cauldron, Suspended|dmg|cauldron}'s {@item iron pot|phb} can hold 1 gallon of liquid, which is equivalent to 8 flasks (pints) of liquid. You can use this conversion to determine the cost of filling a cauldron with an item like {@item alchemist's fire (flask)|phb|alchemist's fire} or {@item Holy Water (flask)|phb|holy water}, as shown below.

entries.name: Acid
entries: The cauldron pours acid onto a 10-foot-square area directly below it. Any creature in the area must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 4d4}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Alchemist's Fire
entries: The cauldron pours 400 gp's worth of {@item alchemist's fire (flask)|phb|alchemist's fire} onto a 10-foot square area directly below it. Any creature in the area must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, a target takes 2 ({@damage 1d4}) fire damage at the start of each of its turns. A creature can end this damage by using its action to make a DC 10 Dexterity check to extinguish the flames.

entries.name: Holy Water
entries: The cauldron pours 200 gp's worth of {@item Holy Water (flask)|phb|holy water} onto a 10-foot square area directly below it. Any desecrated ground in the area is purified, and any fiend or undead in the area must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 14 ({@damage 2d6}) radiant damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Mangonel
entries: {@object mangonel|dmg|Mangonels} and other catapults have a shorter range than trebuchets. This makes them more effective against groups of enemies than structures, provided that they are loaded with projectiles that can harm multiple enemies at once.

entries.name: Jar of Boiling Oil
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 5} to hit, range 300/1,200 ft. (can't hit targets within 60 feet of it), one target. {@h} 22 ({@damage 5d8}) bludgeoning damage, and each creature and object in a 10-foot-radius sphere centered on the target must make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) fire damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Meatbag
entries: The mangonel launches a mass of diseased meat or corpses at a point between 60 feet and 200 feet away from it. Each creature within 15 feet of that point must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw against disease, taking 7 ({@damage 2d6}) necrotic damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. On a failed save, a creature is also {@condition poisoned} until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Scattershot
entries: The mangonel launches a mass of small rocks at a point between 60 feet and 200 feet away from it. Each creature and object within 15 feet of that point must make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) bludgeoning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

entries.name: Siege Tower
entries: If you are looking for inspiration to customize your own {@object siege tower|dmg|siege towers}, consider imbuing a tower with the power of an appropriate spell. For example, perhaps a siege tower might be imbued with the {@spell greater invisibility} spell, allowing the tower and its inhabitants to roll up to a wall without necessarily being detected.

entries.name: Crossbow Turrets
entries: This variant siege tower is equipped with three heavy crossbow for each story of the tower. These crossbow turrets are positioned in front of slats along the side and back walls that allow them to shoot enemies that attempt to approach the tower.

entries.name: Floating Tower
entries: This variant siege tower is helt aloft by an upgraded {@spell Tenser's floating disk} spell. Instead of following a creature, a creature within the tower can use its action to cause it to move up to 30 feet horizontally, abiding by the movement limitations detailed in the original spell.

entries.name: Protective Field
entries: This variant siege tower emits a protective aura of magic out to a radius of 30 feet. The tower and each creature in the aura gain half cover against attacks from outside the field.

entries.name: Trebuchet
entries: {@object trebuchet|dmg|Trebuchets} are already perfect. They don't need any variants. But if you want to try your hand at improving them further, you can take inspiration from the alternative projectiles presented in the sections above.

entries.name: Tucker's Kobolds
entries: To tie this chapter together, I recommend reading {@link Tucker's Kobolds|https://media.wizards.com/2014/downloads/dnd/TuckersKobolds.pdf}. This Dragon Magazine article discusses how even the weakest of creatures can threaten high-level adventurers through a combination of teamwork, traps, and tactical wit.

data.name: Appendix A: Creature Templates
entries: Creature templates are preset modifications and additions you can apply to existing monsters. You can use a creature template to represent the conversion of a specific monster into something new (e.g. a zombie), or you can use one to add variety to an otherwise homogenous group of monsters.

entries.name: Official Templates
entries: The dracolich template and other templates included in the {@book Monster Manual|mm} are examples of templates that transform a given monster into something new. However, the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|dmg} also includes a table for {@table Creating NPCs from Scratch; NPC Features|DMG|NPC Features}, which it states can be applied to existing monsters to cause them to be members of specific races.

entries.name: Usage
entries: The creature templates in this chapter are designed to modify how a given monster behaves in combat. For example, the Berserk Monster template can be used to turn a normally docile beast into a feral horror, while the Lurk template can be used to turn a simple warrior into a stealthy assassin.

entries.name: Typical Changes
entries: A creature template can change any of a monster's statistics, but there are certain statistics that are more likely to be changed than others.

entries.name: Ability Score Adjustments
entries: Some templates will increase or decrease a monster's ability scores. For example, the {@race zombie|dmg} template in the DMG decreases a monster's Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores (to represent the loss of brain function) while also increasing its Strength and Constitution scores (to represent the increase in physical might).

entries.name: Hit Dice
entries: Some templates will increase the number of hit dice possessed by a monster. This can represent a notable increase in physical fortitude, but it may also serve to balance out a significant increase in offensive power granted by other parts of the template.

entries.name: New Proficiencies
entries: A template might grant a monster extra skill or saving throw proficiencies. The former represents the monster being adept at a specific skillset (e.g. being stealthy), while the latter represents the monster having greater physical or mental defenses than others of its kind. If a monster is already proficient in a specific skill, it might gain expertise in that skill, meaning that it can double its proficiency bonus when making a check with that skill. Meanwhile, a monster that is already proficient in a specific saving throw might gain advantage on all saving throws of that type.

entries.name: New Resistances and Immunities
entries: A template might also grant a monster additional damage resistances, damage immunities, or condition immunities (or even damage vulnerabilities). For example, the {@race zombie|dmg} template in the DMG grants a creature immunity to poison damage, {@condition exhaustion}, and the {@condition poisoned} condition, which represents the advantages of its undead physiology compared to the base creature.

entries.name: New Features
entries: Finally, a template is likely to grant a monster access to new traits and abilities as appropriate. For example, the {@race gnoll|dmg} template in the DMG gives a monster the Rampage trait, while the {@race kuo-toa|dmg} template grants a monster the Amphibious, Otherworldly Perception, Slippery, and Sunlight Sensitivity traits.

entries.name: Challenge Rating
entries: Because a template can be applied to so many different monsters, there is no listed value for how it will affect a monster's Challenge Rating; once you apply one of these templates, recalculate the monster's Challenge Rating. For guidance on this matter, see the "Monster Features Revisited" section earlier in this document.

entries.name: Modifying Templates
entries: These templates are just a starting point for your monsters. Don't feel the need to constrain yourself to their limitations, or to avoiding using abilities that aren't mentioned in their descriptions.

It's also worth noting that many of these templates simply piece together some of the monster features discussed earlier in this document. For example, the Bodyguard template simply combines my monster version of the Alert feat with pieces of the Polearm Master and Sentinel feats. Thus, you can view these as example applications of the other content in this document, whereas you are free to ignore or deviate from them as you see fit.

entries.name: List of Templates
entries: The templates below are listed in alphabetical order.

entries.name: Abomination
entries: An abomination is some sort of monster that has been corrupted, diseased, warped, or otherwise changed in some unnatural way. The source of this corruption determines its severity and specific nature.

entries.name: Natural Weapons
entries: If the monster normally uses manufactured weapons, you can give it a natural attack instead. This natural attack deals the same amount of damage as its normal weapon attacks.

entries.name: Senses
entries: The monster gains one new sense of your choice.
The monster also gains one or more of the following traits.

entries.name: Abominable Form
entries: Creatures that can see the monster have disadvantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

entries.name: Amorphous/Boneless
entries: The monster can move through and occupy a space as narrow as 4 inches wide without squeezing.

entries.name: Spider Climb
entries: The monster can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

entries.name: Warped Mind
entries: Monstret har fördel på alla räddningskast på intelligens, visdom och karisma.
The monster also gains one or more of the following abilities.

entries.name: Aura of Madness
entries: Creatures within 20 feet of the monster that aren't aberrations have disadvantage on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws.

entries.name: Feed on Weakness
entries: As a reaction when a creature within 20 feet of the monster fails a saving throw, the monster gains temporary hit points equal to half its Challenge Rating.

entries.name: Frightening Screech (Action; Recharge 5-6)
entries: Each creature within 30 feet of the monster that can hear it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw (DC is Charisma-based) or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the monster's Frightening Screech for the next 24 hours.

entries.name: Stench
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 5 feet of the monster must succeed on a Constitution saving throw (DC is Constitution-based) or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the monster's Stench for 24 hours.

entries.name: Berserk Monster
entries: A berserk monster is some sort of beast or other creature that has gone on an unstoppable rampage. Such creatures are often described to be feral or to have gone mad, and present a threat to anyone unfortunate enough to cross paths with them.

entries.name: Saving Throws
entries: The monster gains proficiency in Wisdom saving throws. If it already has this proficiency, it instead gains advantage on all Wisdom saving throws.

entries.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the monster can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

entries.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, the monster can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

entries.name: Unbreakable (3/Day)
entries: Om monstret är {@condition incapacitated} i början av sin tur, upphör effekten som orsakar detta tillstånd omedelbart för monstret.

entries.name: Bodyguard
entries: A bodyguard is some sort of monster used by others used to protect them from physical harm. Some are trained warriors that use their skills for defense. Others use their brute force to attack a threat until they stop moving.

entries.name: Alert
entries: Monstret har en fördel på initiativkast och visdomskontroller ({@skill Perception}).

entries.name: Guard
entries: Som en reaktion när en allierad till monstret inom 1,5 meter från det träffas av en attack, får monstret sig själv att träffas istället.
The monster also gains one of the following abilities.

entries.name: Hold the Line
entries: As a reaction, the monster can make one melee weapon attack against a creature that enters its reach. If the attack hits, the target's speed is reduced to 0 until the end of the current turn.

entries.name: Protective Retaliation
entries: När en varelse inom 1,5 meter från monstret gör en attack mot en av monstrets allierade kan monstret använda sin reaktion för att göra en närstridsattack mot den attackerande varelsen.

entries.name: Boss Monster
entries: The best way to turn a normal creature into a boss monster is to give it mythic traits and actions. You can use this template if you want an abbreviated process that you can elaborate on later. If you wish to make this monster a solo boss, choose a base creature with a CR that is equal to or slightly less than the average party level.

First, give the monster some legendary resistances and a mythic trait. If you'd like, you can replace Legendary Resistance with one of the alternative traits presented earlier in this document, and you can add extra effects that trigger alongside the mythic trait.

entries.name: Last Stand (Mythic Trait; Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: Om monstret har 0 träffpoäng dör eller faller det inte {@condition unconscious}. Istället återfår det alla sina träffpunkter.

entries.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: Om monstret misslyckas med ett räddningskast kan det välja att lyckas istället.

Next, give the monster three legendary actions; you can adjust this number up or down if you have more or less than four characters in the party. Then, give the monster three of the legendary action options below.

items.name: Move.
items.entry: The monster moves up to half its speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

items.name: Detect.
items.entry: Monstret gör en visdomskontroll ({@skill Perception}).

items.name: At-Will Spell.
items.entry: Monstret kastar en av sina magiska besvärjelser.

items.name: Weak Attack.
items.entry: The monster uses one of its weaker attacks.

items.name: Recharge (Costs 2 Actions).
items.entry: Monstret laddar upp en av sina åtgärder och använder den.

entries: Finally, give the monster three of the mythic actions below.

items.name: Rush.
items.entry: Monstret rör sig upp till sin hastighet utan att provocera fram tillfälliga attacker.

items.name: Strong Attack.
items.entry: The monster uses one of its strong attacks, or it uses one of its weaker attacks twice.

items.name: Assault (Costs 2 Actions).
items.entry: The monster gains advantage on all attack rolls until the end of its next turn.

items.name: Cast a Spell (Costs 2 Actions).
items.entry: Monstret kastar en trollformel.

items.name: Defend (Costs 2 Actions).
items.entry: The monster gains advantage on all saving throws until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Commander
entries: A commander is a monster that is slightly smarter, wiser, or more charismatic compared to its kin or peers, granting it natural leadership skills that it can use in combat. For more guidelines for creating leader monsters, see my {@link Warlord Collection|https://www.gmbinder.com/share/-LtrZrYqZl6TBt8gu9lt} homebrew.

entries.name: Ability Score Adjustment
entries: The monster's Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma score increases by 2.

entries.name: Hit Dice
entries: The monster gains two hit dice.

entries.name: Command Ally
entries: Som en bonusåtgärd kan monstret rikta sig mot en allierad som det kan se inom en radie på 30 fot. Om den allierade kan se och höra monstret kan den göra en vapenattack som en reaktion och får fördel på attackkastet.

entries.name: Leadership (Action; Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: I 1 minut kan monstret uttala ett särskilt kommando eller en varning när en icke-fientlig varelse som det kan se inom 30 fot från det gör en attack eller ett räddningskast. Varelsen kan lägga till en {@dice d4} till sitt kast förutsatt att den kan höra och förstå monstret. En varelse kan dra nytta av endast en ledartärning åt gången. Den här effekten upphör om monstret är {@condition incapacitated}.

entries.name: Dirty Fighter
entries: Whether out of malice, fear, or a strong desire to succeed, a dirty fighter doesn't play by the rules. They will do whatever it takes to win, including taking the cheapest shots possible and ambushing foes in order to ensure the greatest chance of success.
The monster gains one of the following utility-based traits.

entries.name: Battle Adept
entries: Opportunity attacks against the monster have disadvantage, and the monster's opportunity attacks against other creatures have advantage.

entries.name: Brawler
entries: Monstret kan använda sin bonusåtgärd för att försöka {@action grapple} eller {@action shove} att döda en varelse inom dess räckvidd.

entries.name: Cheap Shot (1/Turn)
entries: Om monstret gör en vapenattack med fördel på attackkastet och träffar, kan målet inte ta reaktioner och får sin hastighet halverad fram till slutet av monstrets nästa vändning.

entries.name: Evade Foes
entries: On each of its turns, the monster can use a bonus action to take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Dodge} action.

entries.name: Limited Reactiveness
entries: Monstret kan ta två reaktioner per stridsomgång.
The monster also gains one of the following offense-based traits.

entries.name: Cut Down
entries: The monster has advantage on weapon attack rolls against any creature that has half of its hit points or fewer.

entries.name: Deadly Critical
entries: Monstret får en kritisk träff med ett kast på 19 eller 20 och kastar skadetärningarna tre gånger istället för två.

entries.name: Surprise Attack
entries: Om monstret överraskar en varelse och träffar den med en attack under den första stridsrundan tar målet 7 ({@damage 2d6}) extra skada av attacken.

entries.name: Vicious Retaliation
entries: In response to being hit by a melee attack, the monster can make one melee attack against the attacker.

entries.name: Wounded Fury
entries: While it has half of its hit points or fewer, the monster has advantage on attack rolls. In addition, it deals an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage to any target it hits with a melee attack.

entries.name: Hordling
entries: A hordling is a general term used for any monster that works well in groups. While swarms of demons and undead are the most common examples of hordlings in action, the term can also be used to refer to organized soldiers that work well together.

entries.name: Skills
entries: The monster gains proficiency in the {@skill Athletics} skill. If it already had this proficiency, it gains expertise with the skill instead.

entries.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The monster has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the monster's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.
The monster also gains one of the following traits.

entries.name: Formation Tactics
entries: The monster has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition grappled}, or {@condition restrained} while it is within 5 feet of at least one ally.

entries.name: Group Retaliation
entries: When the monster is reduced to 0 hit points by a melee attack, one ally of the monster can use its reaction to make a melee weapon attack against the attacker.

entries.name: Mob Behavior
entries: The monster can use its bonus action to attempt to {@action grapple} or {@action shove} a creature if at least one of the monster's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

entries.name: Overbearing Pack
entries: The monster has advantage on checks made to {@action grapple} or {@action shove} a creature if at least one of the monster's allies is within 5 feet of the target and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

entries.name: Swarming Rush
entries: The monster adds an additional die of damage to its weapon damage rolls while within 5 feet of an ally that isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

entries.name: Lurk
entries: A lurk is a particularly stealthy monster, which is capable of remaining undetected through either mundane skill or magical abilities.

entries.name: Ability Score Adjustment
entries: The monster's Dexterity score becomes 13 if it was 12 or lower.

entries.name: Skills
entries: The monster gains proficiency in the {@skill Stealth} skill. If it already had this proficiency, it gains expertise with the skill instead.
The monster gains one of the following abilities.

entries.name: Cunning Action
entries: On each of its turns, the monster can use a bonus action to take the {@action Dash}, {@action Disengage}, or {@action Hide} action.

entries.name: Nimble Escape
entries: The monster can take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Hide} action as a bonus action on each of its turns.

entries.name: Shadow Stealth
entries: While in dim light or darkness, the monster can take the {@action Hide} action as a bonus action.
The monster also gains one of the following features.

entries.name: Shroud Self (Action)
entries: The monster turns {@condition invisible} until the end of its next turn. This invisibility ends if the monster makes an attack roll, makes a damage roll, or casts a spell.

entries.name: Skulker
entries: When the monster is hidden from a creature and misses it with a ranged weapon attack, making the attack doesn't reveal the monster's position.

entries.name: Trackless
entries: The monster leaves no tracks to indicate where it has been or where it's headed.

entries.name: Shadow Dweller
entries: A shadow dweller, also referred to as a shadow touched monster, is a being that has been corrupted by the Shadowfell or some other dark power. This corruption tethers them to the darkness and grants them limited control over negative energy.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: The monster gains darkvision out to a range of 60 feet. If it already has darkvision, its range increases by 60 feet.

entries.name: Damage Resistances
entries: The monster has resistance to necrotic damage.

entries.name: Skills
entries: The monster gains proficiency in the {@skill Stealth} skill. If it already had this proficiency, it gains expertise with the skill instead.

entries.name: Living Shadow
entries: While in dim light or darkness, the monster has resistance to damage that isn't force, psychic, or radiant.

entries.name: Shadow Stealth
entries: While in dim light or darkness, the monster can take the {@action Hide} action as a bonus action.

entries.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the monster has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

entries.name: Touch of Death
entries: If the monster deals acid, cold, fire, lightning, or poison damage with any of its abilities, change that damage type to necrotic.

entries.name: Spellcaster
entries: Any sentient monster is capable of becoming a spellcaster through a variety of means. This template provides a quick way for you to add spellcasting to a monster that doesn't already have it.

entries.name: Ability Score Adjustment
entries: The monster's Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma score increases by 2, to a minimum of 13.

entries.name: Spellcasting
entries: The monster's spellcaster level is equal to half its Challenge Rating (rounded up). It is associated with one of the following classes: artificer, bard, cleric, druid, paladin, ranger, sorcerer, warlock, or wizard. Its spellcasting ability and the number of spells it knows or prepares are determined by this class selection.

entries.name: Warrior
entries: A warrior is a monster that uses martial training to enhance their combat capabilities. Only the best warriors can be considered fighters, but even a small amount of training can create a significant gap between a warrior and its peers.

entries.name: Ability Score Adjustment
entries: The monster's Strength or Dexterity score increases by 2.

entries.name: Equipment
entries: The monster gains proficiency in all weapons and armor. Feel free to upgrade its equipment as you see fit.

entries.name: Hit Dice
entries: The monster gains three hit dice.

entries.name: Martial Advantage (1/Turn)
entries: The monster can deal an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage to a creature it hits with a weapon attack if that creature is within 5 feet of an ally of the monster that isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

entries.name: Mooks
entries: A mook is a group-oriented monster that is weaker than other monsters for the purpose of being cut down easily. Compared to a normal monster of its kind, a mook has one-fifth as many hit points, and is worth one-fifth as much XP. However, mooks take half damage from effects that target an area, such as the {@spell fireball} spell.

To make combat fun as fun as possible for melee characters, consider pairing this mook rule with the {@variantrule Cleaving Through Creatures} optional rule. When using these two rules together, you can allow attacks to cleave through mooks that aren't necessarily within the original attack's reach. For example, perhaps the original attack causes the target's corpse to fly backwards, hitting and damaging more mooks in the process. Use discretion when ruling on this, and consider requiring an attacker to expend their movement in cases that wouldn't make sense otherwise.

entries.name: TftYP Reprint: Reduced-Threat Monsters
entries: A reduced-threat monster uses a normal monster's statistics, but it has half the normal hit point maximum and takes a -2 penalty on attack rolls, ability checks, saving throws, and saving throw DCs.

A reduced threat creature that is based on a creature bigger than Large is instead Large. Some specific reduced-threat creatures also make changes to the abilities they can use. A reduced-threat creature is worth half the normal XP earned for defeating it.

entries.name: Where are the Monster Roles?
entries: After all this talk of monster roles, you may have expected the monsters in the appendices here to have them written down somewhere. There are three big reasons why they are absent:

items: I designed these monsters before I came up with these rules, which are an attempt to codify various practices scattered in my brain.
Official monsters don't have them, so perhaps it's best to stick to that format for compatibility reasons.
I'm lazy. Sue me.

entries: It is up to you to discern which role or roles a monster can fill. For most monsters, both in this document and in the official books, it is obvious what role they fill. A {@creature barbarian leader|bmg} is a brute and a leader, a {@creature hobgoblin} is a soldier, a {@creature survivalist|bmg} is a skirmisher, and so on.
That said, when you make your own monsters, you can add a monster's role information on the same line as its Challenge Rating.

variantrule.name: Encounter Building: By Tier
entries: Med ovanstående faktorer i åtanke ska vi skapa några system för att bygga upp möten som du kan använda i stället för de officiella systemen. Det första systemet utnyttjar det nivåbaserade systemet som skapats

entries.name: Acquire Monster Points
entries: Låt oss använda en modifierad form av {@b Giffyglyph's monster points (MP)} för att bygga detta möte. Låt oss först bestämma vår grundläggande budget. Vi ska ta antalet karaktärer i gruppen, lägga till en konstant baserad på andra faktorer och multiplicera resultatet med en annan konstant som bestäms av svårighetsgraden av mötet:

entries.name: Party Strength
entries: Börja med att ge dig själv en mängd MP som är lika stor som antalet karaktärer i din grupp.

Gå nu igenom varje karaktär i gruppen (inklusive allierade NPC:er, om det finns några). Om karaktären har tillgång till kraftfulla förmågor med effektområde eller andra krafter som är särskilt starka {@i when compared to the rest of the party} kan du lägga till ytterligare 1 MP till poolen. Den här justeringen tar hänsyn till karaktärens större inflytande på handlingsekonomin.

entries.name: Difficulty Multiplier
entries: Nu när du har justerat din budget baserat på din grupps styrka kommer vi att ta denna mängd MP och multiplicera den med en konstant baserad på svårighetsgraden.

entries.name: Add Monsters
entries: Därefter spenderar vi dessa monsterpoäng för att lägga till monster i mötet. Monster med högre nivåer kostar mer MP, vilket visas i tabellen nedan. Fortsätt att lägga till monster tills du har använt alla dina MP.

*Den här kostnaden utgår som standard från att fyra hantlangare är ungefär lika stora som en karaktär. Det första avsnittet tar redan hänsyn till karaktärer som har tillgång till särskilt potenta förmågor som kan slå ut stora grupper av hantlangare, så vi behöver inte ta hänsyn till det här. Observera istället att om du använder minions som är särskilt svaga eller starka kan du ändra den här kostnaden till 1/5 MP respektive 1/3 MP.

Följande citat från DMG är relevant här: "När du gör den här beräkningen, räkna inte med några monster vars utmaningsklassning är betydligt lägre än den genomsnittliga utmaningsklassen för de andra monstren i gruppen, såvida du inte tror att de svaga monstren bidrar avsevärt till mötets svårighetsgrad."
**Om ett monster på den här nivån har legendariska åtgärder kan du beräkna att kostnaden är 1 MP plus 1 MP för varje legendarisk åtgärd som det har (vanligtvis totalt 4 MP).

entries.name: DMG Reprint: Challenge Rating and Difficulty
entries: När du sätter ihop ett möte eller äventyr, särskilt på lägre nivåer, ska du vara försiktig när du använder monster vars utmaningsklass är högre än gruppens genomsnittliga nivå. En sådan varelse kan med en enda handling orsaka tillräckligt mycket skada för att slå ut äventyrare på en lägre nivå. Till exempel har ett träsktroll en utmaningsklass på 2, men det kan döda en trollkarl på 1:a nivån med ett enda slag.

Dessutom har vissa monster egenskaper som kan vara svåra eller omöjliga att övervinna för karaktärer på lägre nivå. Till exempel har en rakshasa en utmaningsgrad på 13 och är immun mot trollformler på 6:e nivån och lägre. Trollkarlar på 12:e nivå eller lägre har inga trollformler högre än 6:e nivån, vilket innebär att de inte kommer att kunna påverka rakshasa med sin magi, vilket ger äventyrarna en allvarlig nackdel. Ett sådant möte skulle vara betydligt tuffare för gruppen än vad monstrets utmaningsklassning skulle kunna antyda.

entries.name: Other Costs
entries: Istället för att låta Lair Actions och terrängfunktioner öka svårighetsgraden av ett möte kan du välja att ta hänsyn till dessa faktorer genom att tilldela dem en MP-kostnad. Att lägga till Lair Actions till ett möte, oavsett om de är knutna till ett enskilt monster eller är associerade med en grupp av monster eller till och med själva miljön, kostar 1 extra MP.

Observera också att förstärkningar och kallade varelser påverkar MP precis som vanliga monster, oavsett hur de står i striden. Om du till exempel har en druid i gruppen som kan kasta Conjure Animals kan du öka din MP-budget baserat på hur många varelser du räknar med att de kommer att kallas. Under tiden kostar en demon som är framkallad av en trollkarl eller någon annan djävul MP som vanligt.

entries.name: Customize Your Encounter
entries: Du får gärna anpassa ditt möte så mycket du vill. För det mesta har du en allmän uppfattning om vilken typ av monster som mötet kommer att bestå av baserat på berättelsen i ditt spel. Andra gånger kommer du redan att veta vilken typ av monster som kommer att vara inblandade i striden, så du kommer att använda MP-systemet ovan enbart för att räkna ut hur många monster ett balanserat möte kommer att bestå av.

entries.name: Fine Adjustments
entries: Ju mer du använder detta system, desto bättre blir du på att göra uppskattningar och ändringar vid behov. I idealfallet behöver du inte det här systemet när du väl har lärt dig att balansera möten för ditt specifika sällskap. Därför får du gärna experimentera: skapa ett möte och gör bedömningar vid behov. Om du tycker att ett möte är för svagt eller för starkt, se till att komma ihåg vad du ska ändra till nästa gång.

entries.name: Monster Roles
entries: Om du vill kan du välja monster med roller som du tror kommer att utmana ditt sällskap på ett lämpligt sätt. Till exempel kommer ett möte som består av en brute, en grupp soldater och några krypskyttar att ha flera lager av taktiskt tänkande: att slå ut brute med enstaka målattacker kan vara viktigt, men om soldaterna inte slås ut i tid har de potential att överväldiga gruppen genom sitt antal. Kanske skulle det också vara en bra idé att ta ut krypskyttarna, för att hindra dem från att ostraffat orsaka alltför mycket extra skada; när de är borta kan det bli mycket lättare att ta ner bruten och soldaterna. Med vetskap om vad du vet om ditt partis förmågor (och deras stridsroller, om du så vill) kan skapandet av möten enligt dessa linjer möjliggöra roligt taktiskt tänkande på båda sidor av DM-skärmen.

entries.name: Sample Encounter Compositions
entries: Alla exempel på möten nedan utgår från ett parti med fyra medlemmar och en grundbudget på fyra MP. Använd gärna dessa exempel på möten i ditt eget spel och gör de anpassningar som behövs.

Kom ihåg att du i alla möten, särskilt när de innehåller underhuggare, kan lägga till monster som är mycket svagare än en vanlig underhuggare. Till exempel kan en Fragile Boss-strid för en grupp med karaktärer på 15:e nivån inkludera fyra wights som underhuggare, men du kan också inkludera en hord med tjugo zombies om du känner att wights inte kommer att kunna dra sin egen vikt.

entries.caption: Kill or Capture Squad: Hard Encounter

variantrule.name: Encounter Building: By XP
entries: You may have noticed that the {@variantrule Encounter Building: By Tier|BMG} optional rule covers a wide range of Challenge Ratings with its tiers. This creates more wiggle room for the CRs of your monsters to be adjusted. But it also obfuscates a much larger flaw with the system, which we will discuss and address below.

entries.name: One Versus Many
entries: Som vi tidigare har diskuterat spelar handlingsekonomi en stor roll. Ett solomonster utan legendariska handlingar kommer att bli överväldigad av gruppen, medan en stor svärm av svagare monster kan göra det motsatta. Därför är det nödvändigt att ta hänsyn till det när du balanserar dina möten.

The thing is, the encounter building system in the previous section, as well as the one presented in {@book Dungeon Xanathar's Guide to Everything|xge}, doesn't account for it at all. In my case, one champion is weighed the same as two elites, four standards, or sixteen minions. But in an actual encounter, including four standard monsters might make the fight much harder for the party than including two elites would. And even with area of effect spells like {@spell fireball} taken into account, sixteen minions can present a huge threat to the party if the conditions are right. If you don't balance the action economy separately while using these systems, using either of these systems haphazardly can lead to a party wipe.

entries.name: The Original System
entries: {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|dmg} är ett exakt system för balansering av möten som bygger på XP-värdena för monstren i mötet. För att ta hänsyn till handlingsekonomin lägger de till ett extra steg i processen som heter "Modify Total XP for Multiple Monsters". Under detta sista steg säger DMG att du ska multiplicera monstrens totala XP med en multiplikator som bestäms av antalet monster i mötet.

While this concept is a good one, the multipliers themselves make no sense. They start with one monster being times 1, scaling upwards as you add more monsters. But, we already know that solo monsters generally tend to get dogpiled. Shouldn't the multiplier of 1 apply when there are an equal number of combatants on both sides? Speaking of, why don't these multipliers account for varying party sizes at all? Finally, why are the multipliers presented for specific ranges of CRs, causing significant gaps to form between them all?

entries.name: Tweaking the System
entries: Låt oss ändra steg 4 i DMG:s process för att skapa möten genom att skapa våra egna multiplikatorer och ta hänsyn till de klagomål som presenterats ovan.
Först och främst måste vi ta hänsyn till partiets storlek. De multiplikatorer vi kommer fram till bör delas med antalet partimedlemmar.

Next, let's establish a multiplier of 1 for when the number of monsters equals the number of players. Having less monsters should yield a multiplier of less than 1, and having more should yield a multiplier that is greater than 1.

Finally, let's make this new multiplier formula more precise by not using ranges of monsters, instead creating a continuous function: the function's main input will be the number of monsters, and its output will be the XP multiplier we need.
With all of these facts, we can replace step 4 of the "Creating a Combat Encounter" process in the DMG with the calculation presented below.

entries.name: Revised: Modify Total XP for Multiple Monsters
entries: The more monsters there are in the encounter, the more attack rolls you're making against the characters in a given round, and the more dangerous the encounter becomes. To correctly gauge an encounter's difficulty, multiply the total XP of all the monsters in the encounter by the value given below:

items: If the encounter includes only 1 or 2 monsters, the multiplier is equal to 3 × the number of characters in the party.
If the encounter includes 3 or more monsters, the multiplier is equal to the number of monsters × the number of characters in the party.

entries: When making this calculation, don't count any monsters whose challenge rating is significantly below the average challenge rating of the other monsters in the group unless you think the weak monsters significantly contribute to the difficulty of the encounter.

variantrule.name: Creature Templates
entries: Creature templates are preset modifications and additions you can apply to existing monsters. You can use a creature template to represent the conversion of a specific monster into something new (e.g. a zombie), or you can use one to add variety to an otherwise homogenous group of monsters.

entries.name: Official Templates
entries: The dracolich template and other templates included in the {@book Monster Manual|mm} are examples of templates that transform a given monster into something new. However, the {@book Dungeon Master's Guide|dmg} also includes a table for {@table Creating NPCs from Scratch; NPC Features|DMG|NPC Features}, which it states can be applied to existing monsters to cause them to be members of specific races.

entries.name: Usage
entries: The creature templates in this chapter are designed to modify how a given monster behaves in combat. For example, the Berserk Monster template can be used to turn a normally docile beast into a feral horror, while the Lurk template can be used to turn a simple warrior into a stealthy assassin.

entries.name: Typical Changes
entries: A creature template can change any of a monster's statistics, but there are certain statistics that are more likely to be changed than others.

entries.name: Ability Score Adjustments
entries: Some templates will increase or decrease a monster's ability scores. For example, the {@race zombie|dmg} template in the DMG decreases a monster's Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores (to represent the loss of brain function) while also increasing its Strength and Constitution scores (to represent the increase in physical might).

entries.name: Hit Dice
entries: Some templates will increase the number of hit dice possessed by a monster. This can represent a notable increase in physical fortitude, but it may also serve to balance out a significant increase in offensive power granted by other parts of the template.

entries.name: New Proficiencies
entries: A template might grant a monster extra skill or saving throw proficiencies. The former represents the monster being adept at a specific skillset (e.g. being stealthy), while the latter represents the monster having greater physical or mental defenses than others of its kind. If a monster is already proficient in a specific skill, it might gain expertise in that skill, meaning that it can double its proficiency bonus when making a check with that skill. Meanwhile, a monster that is already proficient in a specific saving throw might gain advantage on all saving throws of that type.

entries.name: New Resistances and Immunities
entries: A template might also grant a monster additional damage resistances, damage immunities, or condition immunities (or even damage vulnerabilities). For example, the {@race zombie|dmg} template in the DMG grants a creature immunity to poison damage, {@condition exhaustion}, and the {@condition poisoned} condition, which represents the advantages of its undead physiology compared to the base creature.

entries.name: New Features
entries: Finally, a template is likely to grant a monster access to new traits and abilities as appropriate. For example, the {@race gnoll|dmg} template in the DMG gives a monster the Rampage trait, while the {@race kuo-toa|dmg} template grants a monster the Amphibious, Otherworldly Perception, Slippery, and Sunlight Sensitivity traits.

entries.name: Challenge Rating
entries: Because a template can be applied to so many different monsters, there is no listed value for how it will affect a monster's Challenge Rating; once you apply one of these templates, recalculate the monster's Challenge Rating. For guidance on this matter, see the "Monster Features Revisited" section earlier in this document.

entries.name: Modifying Templates
entries: These templates are just a starting point for your monsters. Don't feel the need to constrain yourself to their limitations, or to avoiding using abilities that aren't mentioned in their descriptions.

It's also worth noting that many of these templates simply piece together some of the monster features discussed earlier in this document. For example, the Bodyguard template simply combines my monster version of the Alert feat with pieces of the Polearm Master and Sentinel feats. Thus, you can view these as example applications of the other content in this document, whereas you are free to ignore or deviate from them as you see fit.

entries.name: List of Templates
entries: The templates below are listed in alphabetical order.

entries.name: Abomination
entries: An abomination is some sort of monster that has been corrupted, diseased, warped, or otherwise changed in some unnatural way. The source of this corruption determines its severity and specific nature.

entries.name: Natural Weapons
entries: If the monster normally uses manufactured weapons, you can give it a natural attack instead. This natural attack deals the same amount of damage as its normal weapon attacks.

entries.name: Senses
entries: The monster gains one new sense of your choice.
The monster also gains one or more of the following traits.

entries.name: Abominable Form
entries: Creatures that can see the monster have disadvantage on saving throws against being {@condition frightened}.

entries.name: Amorphous/Boneless
entries: The monster can move through and occupy a space as narrow as 4 inches wide without squeezing.

entries.name: Spider Climb
entries: The monster can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

entries.name: Warped Mind
entries: Monstret har fördel på alla räddningskast på intelligens, visdom och karisma.
The monster also gains one or more of the following abilities.

entries.name: Aura of Madness
entries: Creatures within 20 feet of the monster that aren't aberrations have disadvantage on Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma saving throws.

entries.name: Feed on Weakness
entries: As a reaction when a creature within 20 feet of the monster fails a saving throw, the monster gains temporary hit points equal to half its Challenge Rating.

entries.name: Frightening Screech (Action; Recharge 5-6)
entries: Each creature within 30 feet of the monster that can hear it must succeed on a Wisdom saving throw (DC is Charisma-based) or be {@condition frightened} for 1 minute. A creature can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the effect on itself on a success. If a creature's saving throw is successful or the effect ends for it, the creature is immune to the monster's Frightening Screech for the next 24 hours.

entries.name: Stench
entries: Any creature that starts its turn within 5 feet of the monster must succeed on a Constitution saving throw (DC is Constitution-based) or be {@condition poisoned} until the start of its next turn. On a successful saving throw, the creature is immune to the monster's Stench for 24 hours.

entries.name: Berserk Monster
entries: A berserk monster is some sort of beast or other creature that has gone on an unstoppable rampage. Such creatures are often described to be feral or to have gone mad, and present a threat to anyone unfortunate enough to cross paths with them.

entries.name: Saving Throws
entries: The monster gains proficiency in Wisdom saving throws. If it already has this proficiency, it instead gains advantage on all Wisdom saving throws.

entries.name: Aggressive
entries: As a bonus action, the monster can move up to its speed toward a hostile creature that it can see.

entries.name: Reckless
entries: At the start of its turn, the monster can gain advantage on all melee weapon attack rolls during that turn, but attack rolls against it have advantage until the start of its next turn.

entries.name: Unbreakable (3/Day)
entries: Om monstret är {@condition incapacitated} i början av sin tur, upphör effekten som orsakar detta tillstånd omedelbart för monstret.

entries.name: Bodyguard
entries: A bodyguard is some sort of monster used by others used to protect them from physical harm. Some are trained warriors that use their skills for defense. Others use their brute force to attack a threat until they stop moving.

entries.name: Alert
entries: Monstret har en fördel på initiativkast och visdomskontroller ({@skill Perception}).

entries.name: Guard
entries: Som en reaktion när en allierad till monstret inom 1,5 meter från det träffas av en attack, får monstret sig själv att träffas istället.
The monster also gains one of the following abilities.

entries.name: Hold the Line
entries: As a reaction, the monster can make one melee weapon attack against a creature that enters its reach. If the attack hits, the target's speed is reduced to 0 until the end of the current turn.

entries.name: Protective Retaliation
entries: När en varelse inom 1,5 meter från monstret gör en attack mot en av monstrets allierade kan monstret använda sin reaktion för att göra en närstridsattack mot den attackerande varelsen.

entries.name: Boss Monster
entries: The best way to turn a normal creature into a boss monster is to give it mythic traits and actions. You can use this template if you want an abbreviated process that you can elaborate on later. If you wish to make this monster a solo boss, choose a base creature with a CR that is equal to or slightly less than the average party level.

First, give the monster some legendary resistances and a mythic trait. If you'd like, you can replace Legendary Resistance with one of the alternative traits presented earlier in this document, and you can add extra effects that trigger alongside the mythic trait.

entries.name: Last Stand (Mythic Trait; Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: Om monstret har 0 träffpoäng dör eller faller det inte {@condition unconscious}. Istället återfår det alla sina träffpunkter.

entries.name: Legendary Resistance (3/Day)
entries: Om monstret misslyckas med ett räddningskast kan det välja att lyckas istället.

Next, give the monster three legendary actions; you can adjust this number up or down if you have more or less than four characters in the party. Then, give the monster three of the legendary action options below.

items.name: Move.
items.entry: The monster moves up to half its speed without provoking opportunity attacks.

items.name: Detect.
items.entry: Monstret gör en visdomskontroll ({@skill Perception}).

items.name: At-Will Spell.
items.entry: Monstret kastar en av sina magiska besvärjelser.

items.name: Weak Attack.
items.entry: The monster uses one of its weaker attacks.

items.name: Recharge (Costs 2 Actions).
items.entry: Monstret laddar upp en av sina åtgärder och använder den.

entries: Finally, give the monster three of the mythic actions below.

items.name: Rush.
items.entry: Monstret rör sig upp till sin hastighet utan att provocera fram tillfälliga attacker.

items.name: Strong Attack.
items.entry: The monster uses one of its strong attacks, or it uses one of its weaker attacks twice.

items.name: Assault (Costs 2 Actions).
items.entry: The monster gains advantage on all attack rolls until the end of its next turn.

items.name: Cast a Spell (Costs 2 Actions).
items.entry: Monstret kastar en trollformel.

items.name: Defend (Costs 2 Actions).
items.entry: The monster gains advantage on all saving throws until the end of its next turn.

entries.name: Commander
entries: A commander is a monster that is slightly smarter, wiser, or more charismatic compared to its kin or peers, granting it natural leadership skills that it can use in combat. For more guidelines for creating leader monsters, see my {@link Warlord Collection|https://www.gmbinder.com/share/-LtrZrYqZl6TBt8gu9lt} homebrew.

entries.name: Ability Score Adjustment
entries: The monster's Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma score increases by 2.

entries.name: Hit Dice
entries: The monster gains two hit dice.

entries.name: Command Ally
entries: Som en bonusåtgärd kan monstret rikta sig mot en allierad som det kan se inom en radie på 30 fot. Om den allierade kan se och höra monstret kan den göra en vapenattack som en reaktion och får fördel på attackkastet.

entries.name: Leadership (Action; Recharges after a Short or Long Rest)
entries: I 1 minut kan monstret uttala ett särskilt kommando eller en varning när en icke-fientlig varelse som det kan se inom 30 fot från det gör en attack eller ett räddningskast. Varelsen kan lägga till en {@dice d4} till sitt kast förutsatt att den kan höra och förstå monstret. En varelse kan dra nytta av endast en ledartärning åt gången. Den här effekten upphör om monstret är {@condition incapacitated}.

entries.name: Dirty Fighter
entries: Whether out of malice, fear, or a strong desire to succeed, a dirty fighter doesn't play by the rules. They will do whatever it takes to win, including taking the cheapest shots possible and ambushing foes in order to ensure the greatest chance of success.
The monster gains one of the following utility-based traits.

entries.name: Battle Adept
entries: Opportunity attacks against the monster have disadvantage, and the monster's opportunity attacks against other creatures have advantage.

entries.name: Brawler
entries: Monstret kan använda sin bonusåtgärd för att försöka {@action grapple} eller {@action shove} att döda en varelse inom dess räckvidd.

entries.name: Cheap Shot (1/Turn)
entries: Om monstret gör en vapenattack med fördel på attackkastet och träffar, kan målet inte ta reaktioner och får sin hastighet halverad fram till slutet av monstrets nästa vändning.

entries.name: Evade Foes
entries: On each of its turns, the monster can use a bonus action to take the {@action Disengage} or {@action Dodge} action.

entries.name: Limited Reactiveness
entries: Monstret kan ta två reaktioner per stridsomgång.
The monster also gains one of the following offense-based traits.

entries.name: Cut Down
entries: The monster has advantage on weapon attack rolls against any creature that has half of its hit points or fewer.

entries.name: Deadly Critical
entries: Monstret får en kritisk träff med ett kast på 19 eller 20 och kastar skadetärningarna tre gånger istället för två.

entries.name: Surprise Attack
entries: Om monstret överraskar en varelse och träffar den med en attack under den första stridsrundan tar målet 7 ({@damage 2d6}) extra skada av attacken.

entries.name: Vicious Retaliation
entries: In response to being hit by a melee attack, the monster can make one melee attack against the attacker.

entries.name: Wounded Fury
entries: While it has half of its hit points or fewer, the monster has advantage on attack rolls. In addition, it deals an extra 7 ({@damage 2d6}) damage to any target it hits with a melee attack.

entries.name: Hordling
entries: A hordling is a general term used for any monster that works well in groups. While swarms of demons and undead are the most common examples of hordlings in action, the term can also be used to refer to organized soldiers that work well together.

entries.name: Skills
entries: The monster gains proficiency in the {@skill Athletics} skill. If it already had this proficiency, it gains expertise with the skill instead.

entries.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The monster has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the monster's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.
The monster also gains one of the following traits.

entries.name: Formation Tactics
entries: The monster has advantage on saving throws against being {@condition charmed}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition grappled}, or {@condition restrained} while it is within 5 feet of at least one ally.

entries.name: Group Retaliation
entries: When the monster is reduced to 0 hit points by a melee attack, one ally of the monster can use its reaction to make a melee weapon attack against the attacker.

entries.name: Mob Behavior
